Posts.Content: Thank so much for your reply. Yes, I'd even read that stress/anxiety can result in a high PSA test - which I am indeed experiencing lately. I will try to stop worrying, and follow the steps I need to. Thanks for those tips on preparing for the retesting.
Posts.Title: 43 y/o, PSA=6. Retest and urologist app't in New Year

Posts.Content: I just received the results of most recent PSA, which showed 0.61. I followed OTAGO's guidance on pre-PSA activity (or lack of activity). There were some other elevated blood tests when I got my first PSA back in December, and they are all back down to normal range too. Very odd. For my age, I think 0.61 is still a bit of a concern, and I\m scheduled to have my DRE on Thursday. Thanks all for your feedback here.

Posts.Title: 43 y/o, PSA=6. Retest and urologist app't in New Year

Posts.Content: Hi there. Just thought I'd come have a browse around this site and post about my situation. Over the past year, I've had a three episodes of penile discharge. The first time, the Doctor gave me two types of antibiotics to take, and sent me for STI tests - all negative. The second time, Dr. gave me both antibiotics again, and sent me for STI tests, and this time, a culture of the discharge rather than just urinalysis. The culture was clear, but the analysis said, "Many neutrophils". I didn't get a call from the Dr, so assumed the "Many neutrophils" thing was nothing. Plus, it seemed obvious that there would be given there was discharge, and the antibiotics cleared it up. I have been in good shape and eat reasonably. In fact, I ran a half-marathon at the end of September. In mid-November, I developed diarrhea. I still feel fine other than a bit of discomfort in my gut, and I'm actually gaining a bit of weight as I don't exercise as much in the winter. I also got the penile discharge again (minor this time) in the past couple weeks, that actually went away on its own after a week, so by the time I went to the Dr it was gone, but I did tell her about it, and the diarrhea was my issue. She sent me for a complete round of blood tests, urinalysis, and stool sample (culture and parasite) and everything was normal - except PSA of 6, which she said is "very high" for someone my age. I had been taking Proscar for a year (for hair loss), and stopped in October, and the Dr. wondered if it is could be a "rebound" from stopping the Proscar given that the drug suppresses PSA readings. I have just resumed taking Proscar (Dr. said it was fine). Now, I've been referred to a urologist for a DRE, and I have a PSA re-test. The Dr. hesitated, but prescribed a two week course of Cipro to address the diarrhea and potential prostatitis. I'm on day 5 of the Cipro, and the diarrhea is improving. I have none of the typical symptoms of PC, no pain or swelling in my crotch or anywhere else, no trouble or pain peeing etc. Of course, I know that this lack of typical symptoms doesn't mean anything in terms of a PC diagnosis. Anyway, it all seems very weird to me... and of course, the a bad scenario here is that the previous Doctors should have investigated the discharge further, and because they didn't, it may well be Prostrate Cancer that has spread into my bowel - causing the diarrhea. Of course, the best case scenario is that the two are unrelated, the Cipro kills the bugs causing the diarrhea and the prostate infection. I guess I don't have a question really, but just wanted to type this out. I haven't shared this with anyone yet of course.

Posts.Title: 43 y/o, PSA=6. Retest and urologist app't in New Year

Posts.Content: Hi again. Just an interim update. I took two weeks of Cipro, and there has been only minor improvement in the diarrhea situation. Unfortunately my appointment with the urologist did not get scheduled until next week. December 20 is when my GP referred me - a long wait time, but she said he is an excellent urologist. I am having all new blood work and my PSA retest in a couple days. I'll provide another update after my urology appointment.
